awd_titl_txt: Sulfur Isotopic Evidence on the Age of Recycled Surface Material in the Tristan-Gough Plume Source
awd_abstract_narration:
The Earth as we know it today evolved over more than 4.5 billion years through accretion, catastrophic impacts, formation of oceanic crust and continents and establishing plate tectonics. Learning about this evolution is extremely difficult because the memory of this evolution is in rocks but almost all of them have been recycled in our dynamic Earth. An exception are ocean islands (e.g. Hawaii, Galapagos) that are formed by upwellings (mantle plumes) from the core-mantle boundary and represent material that witnessed surface conditions of the Earth a long time ago. But how long ago? This is generally not yet known. Although the age of a volcanic rock can be measured, the age of the source of a volcanic rock cannot. A recently developed tool to address this question looks at sulfur. The atmosphere changed about 2.45 billion years ago when oxygen increased dramatically, the so-called Great Oxygenation Event. The composition of sulfur in contact with the atmosphere before and after this 2.45 billion year mark are very different. Thus it can be determined if sulfur was on the surface of Earth before or after 2.45 billion years ago. Previous studies have found that sulfur from the surface of Earth more than 2.45 billion years ago traveled to the core-mantle boundary some 3000 km deep and back up where it was carried in magmas to the surface. This is an excellent example how the surface of our planet shapes its interior all the way down to the core. In this project sulfur will be used for the first time to investigate one of the major plume systems that have formed flood basalts covering most of Brazil about 130 Ma ago followed by lines of volcanoes marking the passage of the plates over a stationary mantle plume. This project will constrain the age of the source of this major plume system to younger or older than 2.45 billion years. It will also help our understanding how volumetrically significant material older than 2.45 billion year-old material is in the formation of mantle plumes. It has surprised researchers that mantle plume sources can be so old. It is exciting to look at a volcanic eruption and know that what forms lava today had been at the surface of Earth when no higher life forms yet existed, traveled all the way to the core-mantle boundary, and came back up over more than half of Earth's history. 

The persistence of recycled surface sulfur through subduction and eventual rise in a mantle plume has been demonstrated for two smaller South Pacific plumes (Pitcairn and Mangaia island of Cook-Austral) with basalts including sulfur older than about 2.45 Ga. However, to this point it is not clear whether such old surface material is a common or rare component in plume sources. In this project for the first time sulfur isotopes are measured in rocks related to a major long-lived plume system, the Tristan-Gough plume system in the South Atlantic, with an initial flood basalt province, the Parana, and with a root at the core-mantle boundary related to the African large low shear wave velocity province. This project addresses the following major hypothesis through a detailed analyses of sulfide inclusions in volcanic rocks from Tristan and Gough island: 1. Is the recycled component in the Tristan-Gough plume of Archean age or younger? Previous work showed that the Gough signature persists since at least 100 Ma, thus an Archean age would indicate that a significant volume of a major plume source contains old recycled surface material. 2. How does the absence or presence of Archean sulfur relate to the global endmembers of oceanic basalts in Sr-Nd-Hf-Pb isotopic compositions? Pitcairn and Tristan-Gough both have enriched mantle 1 endmember compositions. Do sulfur isotopes support formation by similar geochemical fractionation events of similar age, or, do different evolution paths lead to similar compositions? 3. What do sulfur isotopes imply regarding contributions from atmospheric, deep ocean hydrothermal or even microbial sediment components?

por.por_cntn:
Instead of looking to the stars, this project looks deep into our planet. It shows how the chemistry of a few volcanic rocks can piece together a geological story stretching over more than half the age of the Earth and reaching from its surface to the ~3000 km deep core-mantle boundary.

Plate tectonics causes subduction of oceanic plates into the Earth?s mantle but how long this process has been going on and what exactly happens to the subducted oceanic crust is still a matter of debate. Mantle plumes are hot material that rises up from deep within the Earth?s mantle and forms magmas that build up volcanic islands such as Hawaii in the Pacific, as well as Tristan and Gough islands in the South Atlantic. Thus these volcanic islands allow us to get a glimpse at material as deep as the core-mantle boundary. Whether such plumes are formed from subducted oceanic crust and how long ago this subduction might have happened are open questions. Particularly to determine the age has not been possible. Sulfur isotopes have emerged in the last few years as a promising tool to answer these questions of age and surface origin. Sulfur isotopes can identify whether sulfur is older than 2.45 billion years. The way this works is that only during those early times when there was little oxygen in the atmosphere, sulfur was changed in the atmosphere by solar radiation, forming so-called mass-independently fractionated sulfur isotopic compositions (MIF-S) that then rained onto the oceanic plate and was subducted into the mantle. So when we measure MIF-S in mineral-hosted sulfide inclusions in volcanic rocks, we know that the magma formed from material that once resided at the surface of the Earth and that this surface material is older than 2.45 billion years. The first pioneering studies on the islands of Mangaia and Pitcairn in the Pacific found that tiny droplets of sulfides in their volcanic rocks have indeed MIF-S, proofing that subduction occurred a mind-boggling >2.45 billion years ago and that the subducted material resided in the Earth?s mantle for that long until rising in a mantle plume and forming these young islands.

The current project took this important tool and investigated lavas from the most prominent mantle plume in the South Atlantic, the Tristan-Gough plume. This plume has a root at the core-mantle boundary. The islands of Tristan and Gough have distinct chemical signatures that reflect different plume source components and we measured sulfur isotopes on each of the two components to constrain possible differences in the age of the related plume source materials.

47 sulfide inclusion from the island group of Tristan and Gough Island were analyzed. Tristan shows no MIF-S and its source most likely is younger than 2.45 billion years. Most inclusions from Gough present without MIF-S. Importantly, one isolated inclusion from Gough shows a small positive MIF-S signature, which indicates material older than 2.45 billion years in its related mantle plume source. The presence of MIF-S also further strengthens earlier studies that suggested a sediment component in the mantle plume source of Gough.

Differences in olivine trace element compositions in volcanic rocks can distinguish the mineralogy of the related mantle plume, between recycled oceanic crust (pyroxenitic) and normal mantle material (peridotitic). Olivines from Gough Island measured in this project display a pyroxenitic source, therefore supporting a source of subducted oceanic crust. 

To this point MIF-S are only observed in enriched mantle 1 (EMI) islands (Pitcairn and Gough) and the high mu (HIMU) island of Mangaia. A possible common origin is investigated. We find that the trace element signature of Gough EMI is strikingly complementary to Mangaia HIMU. Previously it was proposed that HIMU reflects a carbonatitic component from recycled oceanic crust. Here we propose that Gough EMI could represent the residual oceanic crust after release of the HIMU component, both from a single subducting oceanic plate. Modeling of their Pb isotopic compositions requires this differentiation into EMI and HIMU to be much younger than the 2.45 billion years based on MIF-S. We conclude that the only plausible location of differentiation is the transition zone. The geological story goes as follows: Formation of MIF-S in the >2.45 billion year old atmosphere, sulfur rains down onto oceanic plate and is subducted into the mantle. Storage in the transition zone. About 800 million years ago, release of the carbonatitic HIMU component that gets added to the surrounding mantle. The residual oceanic crust is the EMI component. Both descend to the core-mantle boundary. EMI and HIMU material heats up at the core-mantle boundary and rises as mantle plumes, forming oceanic islands. We sampled these oceanic islands and this is the story they told us.
